image.altText: A court building with arches

props.synopsis: The fees of a private investigator who charged more than $250,000 for his "unnecessary" work in a medical negligence lawsuit, despite having no relevant qualifications, were "excessive", a South Australian Supreme Court has found.

title.children: SA government not liable for 'excessive' private investigator fees in medical negligence claim

image.altText: The fascination that many Australians appear to have with the case of the missing Beaumont children is ethically fraught, as is the media's coverage of it.

props.synopsis: A former factory site linked to the 59-year-old the disappearance of the Beaumont children, which remains one of the nation's most baffling and tragic cold cases, will be searched a third time before being put up for sale, an SA MP says.

title.children: Beaumont children dig prompted by 'new information' about site linked to mystery

image.altText: An artist's impression of an overhead view of the proposed Whyalla hydrogen project.

props.synopsis: Four years after the South Australian government's bold and ambitious — but very much hypothetical — hydrogen power plant was first announced, there have been inauspicious developments concerning its future.

title.children: Will SA's $593m hydrogen power plant proposal vanish into thin air?

image.altText: A sign that reads Renmark High School with the SA government logo at the bottom.

props.synopsis: The identification of three external providers approved to operate in the state's public schools follows a presentation given to year 9 students last year that allegedly included bestiality references.

title.children: SA school given list of approved sex education providers

image.altText: A woman with dark red hair pays for her coffee at a counter in a cafe.

props.synopsis: Small business owners in popular holiday towns say phones and EFTPOS often drop out during peak season, causing a real impact on their sales.

title.children: When the tourists pour in, the internet drops out in holiday towns

props.synopsis: The former deputy leader of South Australia's Child Protection Department, believed to be the first Aboriginal person appointed to the role, has accused his former workplace of racism, claiming the agency told him it "owned" him for the duration of his contract.

title.children: Former SA Child Protection Department deputy says agency told him it 'owned' him

image.altText: The carcass of a dwarf sperm whale.

props.synopsis: The carcass of a dwarf sperm whale is found washed up on an Adelaide beach, with a local tour boat operator who says he saw the "very rare" animal when it was alive and several kilometres offshore describing the cause of death as a "complete mystery".

title.children: Rare whale washes up on SA beach, but cause of death a 'complete mystery'

image.altText: Two RSL officials with what is believed to be a wartime diary.

props.synopsis: An Adelaide RSL is searching for the mystery owner of what is believed to be a World War I diary after it was left on its doorstep.

title.children: Search for origin of diary from WWI left on RSL's doorstep

image.altText: Large plumes of smoke rise from a fire burning across scrub land.

props.synopsis: The CFS said the fire posed no threat to life or property but remains uncontained.

title.children: Flinders Ranges bushfire destroys 20pc of national park in four days

image.altText: Older woman wearing blue shirt sitting in car looking out front window.

props.synopsis: Two-thirds of retired renters are in poverty, according to new analysis from the Grattan Institute, with calls for the major parties to increase Rent Assistance to ease the burden.

title.children: Nearly 4 in 5 retired single women who rent are below the poverty line

image.altText: Patrick Mahomes is pursued by Philadelphia defender Milton Williams in the Super Bowl.

props.synopsis: Kansas City Chiefs quarterback Patrick Mahomes throws a pick-six late in the first half of Super Bowl LIX as the two-time NFL champions fall further behind the Philadelphia Eagles. Follow live.

title.children: Chiefs superstar Mahomes rattled as Eagles build Super Bowl lead

image.altText: fresh fruit in aisles of a grocery shop

props.synopsis: With grocery prices in remote communities costing double on average compared to capital cities, the federal government will lock the price of 30 essential products in remote stores to city prices.

title.children: Albanese promises to lock grocery prices in remote stores to city prices

image.altText: A young boy in a t-shirt that says 'lawnmower boys'

props.synopsis: The death of Perth schoolboy Cassius Turvey will be thrust back into the spotlight today with the scheduled start of the trial of his four alleged murderers in WA's Supreme Court.

title.children: Four people accused of murdering Cassius Turvey to stand trial today

image.altText: the outside of a building

props.synopsis: A legal battle between Star Entertainment and the corporate regulator heads to Federal Court. Hong Kong investors are circling Star's stake in the Queen's Wharf casino complex. The ASX falls as Donald Trump flags further tariffs. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Star confirms Brisbane casino bid as former directors face court

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Tariffs on aluminium and steel to have 'minimal' impact on Australia
ASX 200 opens 0.6% lower on trade fears
ASIC v Star kicks off in Sydney

image.altText: people getting off the metro bus

props.synopsis: Public transport patronage is up nearly 20 per cent since the launch of 50c fares, new data shows.

title.children: Queensland's 50c fares have hit the six-month mark. Here's the verdict

image.altText: Aerial view of flooded houses on an island.

props.synopsis: Hundreds of Australians could be forced to leave their island homes under government plans to safeguard residents against rising sea levels.

title.children: Islanders' fury at 'unbelievable' call for climate change retreat

image.altText: People entering and exiting a subway.

props.synopsis: Many American cities have dire public transport systems, but it hasn't always been this way. How did they get so bad and how does Australia compare?

title.children: Australia's public transport isn't perfect, but at least we're not the US

image.altText: Anthony Albanese and Peter Dutton stand next to each other.

props.synopsis: We are watching the demise of a political system where the two major parties once relied on "safe" seats and fought elections in marginal seats that would swing between them.

title.children: We're watching the demise of the two-party system in real time

image.altText: E-WASTE LAPTOP GENERIC

props.synopsis: Australia produces 500,000 tonnes of e-waste a year but only about half of it is recycled. There are concerns Microsoft's decision to end support for its Windows 10 operating system later this year, which could affect 240 million computers globally, will worsen the problem.

title.children: Microsoft's Windows 10 move could drive landfill surge

image.altText: Inactive traffic lights are seen in the foreground as cars and motorcycles pass on the street below

props.synopsis: Sri Lanka's energy minister says a monkey "came in contact" with a grid transformer in the south of the capital Colombo.

title.children: Nationwide blackout blamed on monkey that broke into Sri Lankan substation

props.synopsis: Around-the-clock coverage of news events as they break, at home and abroad.

title.children: Watch: News Channel

image.altText: Election officials counting votes on a table

props.synopsis: Just a few hundred votes separate the Labor and Liberal candidates in a by-election in Melbourne's west.

title.children: Postal votes could determine tight Werribee by-election

image.altText: Elon Musk raises his hands to his sunglasses as Donald Trump, wearing a MAGA cap, stands behind him.

props.synopsis: US president Donald Trump fends off criticism of Elon Musk's Department of Government Efficiency, saying it will find "hundreds of billions" of US dollars in waste and fraud.

title.children: Trump defends work of Elon Musk's DOGE

image.altText: A burnt-out car is lifted by a tractor in front of an apartment building

props.synopsis: A group of senior Trump administration officials heads to Europe for talks on the Ukraine war, with the US president reportedly claiming to have spoken to his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin.

title.children: US officials head to Europe for top-level talks on Ukraine war

image.altText: An aerial view of a flooded paddock.

props.synopsis: More severe weather is forecast for flood-affected Queenslanders, though the Bureau of Meteorology says there may be some relief later this week.

title.children: More rain on the way for flood-ravaged Queensland residents

image.altText: Abbey McGregor wearing a brown hat and white shirt standing outside

props.synopsis: More than a third of Australians are still working from home, defying a renewed push to get people back into the office post-pandemic.

title.children: Less than half believe WFH is productive but the conversation is nuanced

image.altText: Flames and heavy smoke billow from scrub along a sandy track.

props.synopsis: The Grampians and Little Desert blazes have been brought under control, but firefighters are steeling themselves for treacherous conditions to come.

title.children: Victorian national park fires contained, but heat and wind on the way

image.altText: Marnus Labuschagne, Steve Smith and Kusal Mendis

props.synopsis: Beau Webster redeems himself and Marnus Labuschagne struggles to do the same, as all eyes turn to Lord's in June. Here are the quick hits from the fourth and final day of the second Test in Galle.

title.children: Five quick hits: Webster raises eyebrows as Marnus gets a little relief

image.altText: Foreboding clouds loom over the sea near a coastal town.

props.synopsis: Residents, authorities and pastoralists in the state's north are preparing for a potential cyclone to form tomorrow as a tropical low heads towards "cyclone alley".

title.children: Residents 'battening down the hatches' as potential WA cyclone looms

image.altText: A woman stands next to a waffle iron

props.synopsis: Chef Manjit Kaur, a skilled visa holder, wants permanent residency in Victoria but her boss says Australia's "broken" migration system might see her deported.

title.children: Country cafe 'forced' to cut hours as three chefs face deportation

image.altText: A man leans into the shoulder of another in a big hug.

props.synopsis: Five Thai workers released after being held hostage for more than a year in Gaza have arrived back in Bangkok.

title.children: Released Thai hostages return home after being held in Gaza

image.altText: A man measuring his waistline.

props.synopsis: When BMI, or body mass index, was devised by a Belgian mathematician almost 200 years ago, it was never supposed to be a tool to measure health. Now, researchers are challenging the way obesity is defined and diagnosed.

title.children: ABC News Daily: Why we need to move beyond BMI

image.altText: three school kids running through grounds

props.synopsis: From hair length to skirt length, school uniform policies, or dress codes, dictate many aspects of a student's appearance. But how enforceable are they?

title.children: Can schools enforce uniform policies like short hair for boys and skirts for girls?

image.altText: Image of a medication box with the words "MS-2 Step".

props.synopsis: NSW Health says the government should consider changing legislation so nurse practitioners and endorsed midwives can prescribe medicine for early terminations.

title.children: NSW government to consider allowing nurses to prescribe MS-2 Step

image.altText: An aerial view of fishermen on rocks with a beach in the background.

props.synopsis: First responders want life jackets made compulsory at rock fishing sites across Western Australia after a dramatic reduction in drowning deaths at a notorious south coast beach.

title.children: Only one WA rock fishing site requires life jackets. Should the rule be expanded?
